review_title: Everyone is looking to leave, including myself.
job_title: Instructor in Winter Park, FL
pros: There are none at all.
cons: Pay is low. Long hours. Upper management doesn’t care. Poor management employee communication. Low salaries. Pay ranges from $17 to $25hr to start. It cost about $12,000 out-of-pocket for family health, dental, and eye care a year. That's 25-33% of most starting employees’ income before taxes. So, you are working for $11 to $18 an hour. Then take taxes out after that and you’re lucky to be making $10 to $15 an hour. If you are an instructor, you are required to have a minimum of 4 years of industry experience and a master’s degree in your field, preferably a Ph.D. You might as well work at Target or Mcdonald's these days because you will make more with overtime from those places. After 10 years at 3% annual raises, you will be lucky to be making $33 an hour. After their 1.5% out-of-pocket cost increases on your benefits every year, means you make less and less net each year that you work here adjusted for inflation. It’s a losing proposition to stay here. Owners could totally afford to pay ALL of the employee's out-of-pocket costs, but they don’t. It's a 100% corporate write-off, so why not pay all or a larger share of the benefit-cost for their employees if they don’t want to increase their salaries when they are making hundreds of millions in profit a year? Because it’s a "For the Profit of the Owners and Exec’s business model," not a school concerned with the quality education of its students or the health and welfare of its daily staff who does 99.9% of the hard work.

review_title: Life is what you make it; at Full Sail I've been able to make magic
job_title: Course Director in Clermont, FL
pros: It's going to be different in every department with every supervisor, but it can be a place where instead working the job, you have the freedom and flexibility to make the job work for you. Most people are unaware of their own autonomy. Life is what you make it. I've worked hard to make my life at Full Sail nothing short of magical. Magic is not what they gave me; magic is what I made for myself. As a diverse person, I've been in departments that were very diverse and over time I've seen Full Sail make strides towards becoming as diverse as its student body. No one gets it right every time, but Full Sail is always striving to move forward. From social justice and social change to implementing high tech screening during the global pandemic, Full Sail's leadership has always been one of innovation and to take action first and not follow the trends later out of obligation.
cons: There's rarely an employee anywhere at any level that would not prefer more pay. Yes, there are always people somewhere he make more pay than you or less. After a judicious salary search that is both disciplinary and salary specific, Full Sail's pay for a course director is neither at the top nor the bottom. It's more like 10% softer than the median for your discipline and location.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Instructors are forced to pass every student. So you don't have to grade if you don't want to. No one forces you. In fact they won't allow you to fail a student no matter what. If they are VA, you must pass them to keep the VA cash cow milking.
cons: A huge exodus of longer-term staff in the last couple of years, tells the true story of how horrible Full Sail is to work at. Greedy stakeholders (Owners, CEO and his CIO wife, and upper managers) all want big bonuses, instead of fair pay for the other 90% of the staff (shareholders) that do the actual hard work for the students from Admissions to Education at this “For-Profit” business. Instructors are forced to find a way to pass every student. Everyone's job is to keep the FA and VA cash cow flowing for all the stakeholders’ profits and bonuses at all costs. The stakeholders run the school like a factory where you are a line worker with no power. Nor motivation to do anything extra. Promotions are almost non-existent in their factory system. If they do want you to move up, don’t expect a big pay raise. Just more work for a few more pennies on the dollar. Stakeholders don’t mind raising student tuition costs every year. It now is 70k-100k+ for a degree. But not the pay of the instructors similarly. Students have a general disrespect for their instructors these days because they know they can't be failed. And they know you don't get paid well. When they are paying more in tuition than you make in a year, they feel they can tell you what to do. Like they own you. Currently, there is no long-term reward for working at FS. In fact, it’s the opposite. Turnover is great for keeping wages low! Right! Go, stakeholders. But hey, what do I know, I’m just a little ol' factory worker who knows nothin' bout how to run a successful business long term. I've only worked here 10 years to help the stakeholders build a product that makes huge profits for them. I shouldn't share in that success. Right?

review_title: Avoid this company if you are looking for a living wage, career or passion project.
job_title: Student Advisor in Winter Park, FL
pros: 'If' your department allows you to participate, the cultural development and staff events are lovely and are put on by terrific humans. 'If' your department goes along with it, the culture of politeness and kindness is nice. 'If' you don't need the money to pay for food, shelter or clothing, you can take advantage of the on-campus opportunities.
cons:
The pay here is so low it’s degrading.  Not because the company doesn't have the money, but because the money is diverted to investors and executives.  If you drive past the campus, you will see vehicles that cost in excess of $200,000.  But look to the left and right of those cars and you will see old and rusted out vehicles, because most employees aren’t paid enough money to be able to afford medical insurance, let alone a newer car.  

Excluding investors and executives, if you work at Full Sail University (instructors and admin alike) you will be paid wages around $15.48 and top out at $21.  You may reach $25 if you've worked here in excess of 10 years.  The median income required to live on your own (in a studio rental) in Orange County, which includes you using the snap food program, is $25/hour (NOTE:  This Orange County estimate was put out before the 53%  inflation increase in 2022).  The enormous number of open positions at this school speaks for itself.  

If you plan to move forward in applying for a position here, BE AWARE:

1.	It will take you multiple job applications attempts  before HR will see your resume, let alone read it, process it or contact you.  From the time they first reach out, the hiring process takes between 4 and 6 MONTHS for you to be interviewed, hired, receive paperwork, process paperwork, schedule NEO (new employee orientation) and start working.  And likely you will apply for 20+ jobs before you will be contacted by HR.

2.	Because they cannot keep staff, due to wages so low people literally cannot afford to work there, your job will be to do the work of 2+ people in order to keep hitting the required metrics of your department.  

3.	You will be thoroughly burned out and nobody will feel badly for you or help you.   Not because they don't care, but because if you work at this company, you are constantly under pressure to meet the same goals as when you are fully staffed.  Leads and Managers are under that same relentless pressure to perform.

4.	Unless you have someone else who can equally share the burden of finances (spouse, roommate, etc.), you will HAVE to have a second FULL TIME job in order to afford your average life.  at Full Sail they will tell  you, "Everybody's got a side hustle."  That means that most everyone, executives and investors excluded, has to work a second job in order to afford to work for this company/university.

5.	The pay listed for Full Sail University positions on GlassDoor is wrong.  The university pays 15-35% LESS than GlassDoor says.  Human Resources acknowledges that the GD pay ranges are incorrect.  Also, know that no matter who interviews you for any position, it is company policy to NOT TELL YOU THE SALARY OR HOURLY PAY until the final interview.  Why they hold back such crucial information is unknown.  It seems to be because the pay structure has more to do with seniority, rather than what the position or your necessary skills/experience should be paid.  Someone with a less involved job could be making noticeably more than you due to seniority.   Their pay structure is ineffective.  Even on the internal company career site, wages for positions are kept from current employees as well. 
 
My best advice would be to look to other companies or universities for gainful employment.    The hype and the awards received for work environment and 'best place to work' are not reflective of the experience.  If you like the job description and lack the skill or experience, this is a great place to receive mediocre training, then gain on-the-job 'emergency room' style experience to hone your craft.  Once you hit your 6-month anniversary, apply to other universities/companies for the same position.   The job history looks solid on your resume and you will immediately increase your pay by 30-50%. 

I came to Full Sail University passionate and committed. In the end,  I gave my 2 weeks and left without another word.  I'm sad to share with you that, unfortunately, this is the true culture at this university.  It doesn’t need to be this way, and the people want it to be what we were told it would be, but the executives and investors designed it this way and have chosen to keep it this way.

review_title: Despite the heroic efforts of instructors, this is approaches a predatory degree mill
job_title: Department Chair in Winter Park, FL
pros: Flexible hours, not much experience required, online integration of curriculum, some very good people and some very good instruction happening under duress. There are some cool programs, parts of the campus are nice (though most of it is former strip mall businesses), and there are many wonderful, creative folks.
cons:
There is a combination of low pay, lack of real vacation, and watered down curriculum in the accelerated program. At a regular university, a professor might have 5 classes with 25 students each (probably less than that), which is 125 students max x 2 semesters = 250 student per year with the summers off. If they choose to teach a full load of 2 classes in a summer session, that's another 50 students (plus at least $2000 per class). So let's use 300 students as a comparison. Instructors are required to teach up to 54 students PER MONTH here. In 12 months, that's up to 624 students (not counting adjunct). That's about 2.5 times what a traditional school professor teaches and well over 2 times what that same professor is expected to teach if they also teach a summer session. 

So let's say that college professor makes $50k. On a per student basis, an instructor at Full Sail should make $100-125k. But many make less than $50k and NEVER get a real vacation. The other issue is that most months, many instructors have adjunct sections, which they likely get about $400 after taxes for the month but which represents a 50% increase in workload. For many, this is mandatory. Many colleges also offer exceptional perks, like boosting 401ks and offering free tuition to family and children of full-time employees. Not Full Sail. They give 1% if you take out 5%. That's about as bad as it gets. You also cannot teach elsewhere or risk termination. 

Obviously, if you have to teach more than double the students of professors from elsewhere... something has to give. It's not possible to give high-quality feedback, offer students the amount of learning that compares to a traditional school, and there's a certain amount of "Full Sail doesn't care about me" infecting teachers. Some just try to do really well and inspire, and some, too many, give all students As and copy and paste feedback, like "You think you're using me, but I'm using you, Full Sail." Some instructors even have pride at streamlining their courses online so they don't have to do much. The students lose out. Many programs don't even have any books because FS won't pay for them. 

Management is a nightmare. Most are overpaid, untrained, have never been in charge of people outside of FS, have never taught elsewhere, and worst of all, most have Full Sail degrees or cheap online PhDs. Yet some get paid well over $100k. Someone else mentioned a "toxic positivity." That's very true. There's a lot of patting each other on the back, giving invented awards, marketing changes and decisions to employees, but management lacks the ability to listen, to change, to be fair. They value the superficial over what matters. I once ran into someone who worked at an accounting firm in Winter Park and said, "I can't tell you what the executives make at Full Sail, but let's just say they are easily some of the wealthiest people we do taxes for--in the millions." You can see some of the cars that some of them drive--Porsches, Teslas, Mercedes, Audis, Aston Martins. It's obscene. That transfers to the "marketing" we do: behind the scenes tours, Hall of Fame week, celebrating the no-name HOFers every year, misleading billboards, online ads, etc. There is SO, SO much money from this little school charging the most they possibly can to students, many of whom shouldn't be in college, and the teachers see very little of it. There's a lot of pressure to pass all students. Since COVID, they don't even have to come to class. The CEO is all marketing like a Righteous Gemstones cousin. I heard he even got his pastor a 6 figure job. It's worse than nepotism.

Outsiders that have come in from other institutions haven't lasted long. The way to get ahead is to be social and sing your own praises. No one cares about the core responsibilities of your teaching. In fact, there's a reason why there are no requirements to get into any program as a student. If you can pay, you can do any program. If it's not right for you, you can move to another. And so on. Admissions and advisers push students into graduate programs by telling students whatever they want to hear.

If you want to consider working at FS, you will have to do things the FS way. For many, that means being constantly overworked, underappreciated, and going through management hoops. The reason I think there are so many good reviews here is because people that have never taught anywhere else (or ever even gone to a different college as a student even) have been indoctrinated into the FS way and like the people they work with. Many probably feel lucky to be teaching at this level because they couldn't teach anywhere else above adjunct. Burnout is HIGH. YMMV based on who your management team is. Some are laid back and supportive. Others, like ones I've had, value the superficial and micromanage. This is much more like a corporation than a learning institution. When most of your teachers were taught at FS, and most of those teachers don't have any real teaching experience, it's hard to have a frame of reference for how things should be.

Poor management, unrealistic expectations, unethical work, bad pay. I left this job over a year ago and I still have nightmares about it. You have to have no soul to succeed in this role. 

You are expected to enroll and/or make people apply to Full Sail within a 45 minute phone call; To the extent that you are expected to help prospective students set up their FAFSA ID's. They will tell you that you are helping students follow their dreams, but really you are using old school sales tactics to manipulate disenfranchised people into taking out exorbitant loans to go to Full Sail. The expectations are unrealistic, and you have to be completely heartless to hit the expected metrics every month. Everything you do is monitored (including bathroom time), leading to a very toxic work environment. 

I would not recommend this job to anyone; even my worst enemies.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros:
It's a job, but there's security, even when it may not look like it. I've been there 9 years in the same department.

For the super-hungry, there are opportunities to *network* your way up there ladder, otherwise there's wide room for lateral moves for those who want to try something different.

Consistent employment with a decent benefits packages that helps you slowly pull ahead in the long run.

Extreme flexibility with many departments and managers that allow you to grow within your career externally, while remaining with the university, when doors inside the university may not be available.

For people who are lower on the totem pole, the university has a culture of repeatedly promoting from within the institution.

Consistently one of the best Holiday Parties you'll ever have. The last few year's they rented out Universal Studios Theme Park--all you can ride and all you can eat.
cons:
Pay can be a little soft, but that's largely dependent upon your department and manager.

It is a job so there will be obstacles and pitfalls, but they are all navigable if you don't freak out.

Again, largely department dependent, raises can be soft and not beyond a conservative cost-of-living increase.

job_title: Online Admissions Guide in Winter Park, FL
pros: It’s a paycheck, you can get overtime (not by your choice always)
cons:
Where to begin....I hope there’s no character limit.

1. Management will lie to you and tell you this is not a sales job- it is. You have goals that are not realistic to meet daily/weekly.
2. Pay is terrible. Health benefits aren’t spectacular
3. Your schedule will change daily. You will be on PM shifts most likely for the first 6 months and working weekends as well. 
4. No work life balance. If you were scheduled 12-9, you may be working until 10:30pm or later depending on if you were stuck on a call. If you have somewhere to be they expect your family and friends to just understand that it’s part of the job.
5. Bonuses- They’ll tell you that the position is bonus eligible during the interview, however you’re not eligible for any bonuses until you’ve been there a full year. Even after a year the most you could get was 8k which was based on if you hit your goals each quarter
6. Micromanaged- I have NEVER been so micromanaged in my life. You have to clock your time when you go to the bathroom,lunch, or when you take a break. You’re only allowed (2) 15 minutes breaks a day (if you’re a second late then you will not hit your goals for the day-which your bonuses tie to) , you get a 1 hr unpaid lunch, they expect you to literally be on a phone call and then back on ready to take the next call. They track how much time you are “ready” to take a call each day, you’re only allotted 2 minutes after each call to wrap up any work from the call.
7. Questions- if you asked a question that could possibly put the company in any bad light they would change the subject and not answer the question
8. Turn over rate is INSANE (they will tell you it’s not and that no one leaves-far from true)
9. They don’t value the employees- you’re treated as a number
10. They’ll say it’s all about establishing a connection with the student in training but you will soon then find out that all matters is if you hit your numbers.
11. You’ll be on the phone conducting interviews with students the whole day. 8 hours basically of talking pretty much nonstop.

review_title: It's not a school, it's a factory.
job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: The best thing about Full Sail is the access to software (most of the time) and the wonderful IT support staff.
cons:
The pace is relentless. I'm course director in one of the online degrees, and we are responsible for up to 50 students per month, with a one-week overlap each month (Week 1 of the new month while grading Week 4 from the previous month). Many of us have been "volunteering" to take additional sections each month because of persistent under-staffing. Depending on which department you work in, different rules apply.  Some departments get vacation time when the students have off, some don't. Some departments get credit for teaching what's called "Project Management Assessment" courses (small projects students must complete alongside their course work 3 times during a degree program), while others are forced to generate more "volunteers."
There is no support for attendance at conferences. Budgets take forever to take effect. Most instructors purchase additional software on their own because of this. Often, students have more up to date software than the instructors (sometimes, there has been two versions of separation... students have software x v.3 while instructors have v.1).
The administration regularly refers to the students as clients, which says exactly how much this place is not a school in any meaningful way. Most departments, filled with creative people who have earned Masters Degrees and PhDs are working in small cube farms. They're constructing more of these, and looking for people to do "desk sharing" in the near future. 
My entire department is burnt out, and most of us are looking for work elsewhere. I pray we all find it.

You will find that in not just the students, but a lot of the faculty too seems to be able to hold onto a youthful exuberance. Little to no micro management and work on outside projects i.e. freelance is encouraged. Oh, and Garry Jones is a great guy, may be the best boss you'll ever have.
cons: Hours are unstable, as the place is open 24 hours, and classes change each month. In addition, the scheduling dept. is probably the worst staff around, as often there would be two events or meetings or classes  for you set at different places at the same time. The status of new people and people who have already left may get confused and correspondence is slow. It is also loud, again because of the facility being open 24 hours, you never know what will be happening around the corner.

pros: Great gear, great students, nice weather, awesome coworkers. I loved working there for the first couple of years until they overimplemented the online program, which did not train students in marketable skills.

The administration is sociopathic and only cares about the bottom line.  have over 20 years in the industry, and I have never been lied to my face as much as I was by my superior and other administrators. People get fired for being too high on the salary scale. Faculty trainings are just cult-like indoctrinations. Anyone wanting to change the system is marked as a troublemaker. Your superiors will insist on creepy hugs because of some warped tradition of physical contact. Weird. I worked there for 6 yeas and no one ever asked my opinion on anything. There is not even an employee review process for supervisors. One of my coworkers complained about his abusive program director and was fired the next day.

THE ADMINISTRATION WATERS DOWN REVIEWS BY HAVING MARKETING PEOPLE WRITE POSITIVE REVIEWS. The school is general has been plagued by bad reviews from students, so the marketing department saturates the internet with ads to water down the bad press. Americans have started to catch on to the scam, so now the school markets heavily to foreign students who do not know the American accreditation system and that the degrees are worthless if you want to transfer or go to graduate school.

pros: Great instructors that go above and beyond their job descriptions.  Students are wonderful and very inspiring to be around.
cons:
My direct supervisor has had 100s, if not 1000s of bad critiques from the students.  We still can't figure out why he is still in that position.  
You also need to be an introvert to go anywhere in the company because the people above you are ALL introverted.  Therefore, any show of confidence you may have is directly frowned upon and seen as a threat.  
There are people that have been working in a higher position with more responsibilities that have not been promoted yet or paid for the new responsibilities.  It's paperwork people, not rocket science.
We have monthly critiques by students that we do NOT see. Its literally our only consistent means of feedback for our job besides and ANNUAL review.  How is telling my how I"m doing my job once a year productive????

job_title: Program Director in Winter Park, FL
pros:
It's a very friendly work environment.  People are helpful and generally assist you in any way they can. The school is very progressive in terms of technical needs. Very rarely do you ask for something and have the school say you won't be able to get it. 
Work/Life balance is solid. Yes, there's a lot of work and grading, but the schedule is manageable and most bosses are good about letting you manage your own time.
cons:
The hiring process was long, deliberate and somewhat painful. I felt on numerous occasions I was leaving candidates twisting in the wind a bit.  
As is the case with most educational institutions, the pay for CDs is lower than I would like. Many of our potential hires are coming professional worlds where pay is much better. It would be great to find a way to be a little more competitive with pay to have a better chance to entice someone to come work here.

review_title: Overall a nice place to work and easy to get along with immediate management and co-workers but extremely repetitive.
job_title: Admissions Connection Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Very flexible management and easy work. If you're interested in higher ed, it's a good entry level first start. Co workers are also really nice. For the type of job it is, benefits are ok too.
cons: Extremely repetitive. Call center environment which can make it hard to stay motivated for job. Upper management is obsessive over students/"leads" and will direct us to call them indefinitely - even if they last communicated to us years ago. Also hard to get a good gauge of the direction of the admissions department. Upper management is tight-lipped with employees when you wade through some of their lip-service. While benefits are good, actual pay - especially in Orlando is extremely tough to overcome. Makes the job good for fresh out of high school or maybe college but not much beyond that.

job_title: Outreach Representative in Orlando, FL
pros:
Full Sail, as a whole, is a great company to work for. The culture is great, the benefits are great, and the people (for the most part) are amazing. 
You won't be sitting in an office everyday. You'll be out at educational events, high schools, and other marketing events. 90% of the job is really fun, and your peers are great. The pay is okay for the industry.
cons:
The department management is beginning to ruin this department with hubris. They believe that the success of this department is because of their efforts, and not the efforts of those in the field every single day actually making the numbers that they tout. 
The pay is just okay for the industry. 
They will make you work for free, while saying "wait no doooonnnnttt" because their tunnel vision on leads is so extreme.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Park, FL
pros: Benefits and Employee Appreciation. It is a large business so there are many employment opportunities if you feel comfortable working somewhere that, sadly, takes advantage of students' financially.
cons: Business model for an educational institution = any student with a GED/HS diploma can attend- the focus is on enrolling as many as possible and walking them through the student loan process for very expensive loans- once they are in the door the support drops off. Students from lower SES backgrounds end up with very expensive loans and impractical degrees. It is an excellent school for 25% of the students who have the background and abilities to really make their degrees work for them...sadly the majority of the students flounder while there and many end up having difficulty finding jobs out of school that can pay enough to make up for ridiculous amounts of loans due to the very high tuition. Morally/ethically it was not for me. If the tution was lower and students were provided with more support and prep classes as needed I would have been much more comfortable working there.

review_title: Make Sure You're In the Cool Club.
job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: It's a very laid back atmosphere.  As long as you do your job correctly and your class is up to par and the students like you and the class, everything is golden.
cons: Full Sail treats it's employees very poorly.  For instance, right now, they are having their Course Directors run the on campus classes as well as the online courses, which is basically having them do 2 jobs for the price of one.  People don't get advanced on talent and teaching skills, they get advanced on how much they suck up to the Program Directors.  But the most unfair aspect is the teachers are the lowest people on the totem pole while the people in admissions get paid about twice as much as the teachers do and they get bonuses.

review_title: One of the few jobs that is flexible with classes, so awesome!
job_title: Lab Monitor in Winter Park, FL
pros:
You can choose your own hours. There is a minimum amount you have to complete each month, usually it's around 16 hours. Once you're in finals classes you don't need to meet the requirements but only lab monitors in those classes are allowed to open the rooms. 
But you can get so much extra time to work on your stuff, it's super helpful if you've got a group project in need of a lot of computers. 

You also have the possibility of brushing up your skills in earlier classes, if you help students.
cons:
There doesn't seem to be a limit to the amount of Lab Monitors hired so space is cramped, you might end up having to take 0100 or 0500 labs.
There are a few lab monitors that like to max out their work hours (max is 26/h per week) and take most of the ideal times. If there are a few of these lab monitors you also might get stuck doing 0500 labs. 

Sometimes security can take half an hour to unlock the door.

review_title: Pays the bills, but the job itself is soul crushing.
job_title: Admissions Connection Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Upward mobility, flexible scheduling, and a friendly work environment are some good reasons to think about working for Full Sail University.
cons: The job itself is mindless. You call people who requested information from the school years ago and try to sell them an education, basically. Lots of people we call are angry at us and we get yelled at almost daily. I think that these problems are a part of every call center environment, though. I wouldn't say that these problems are specific to Full Sail University.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Coworkers are mostly friendly.
Job security is pretty high (so far).
Low stress environment (depends on your position).
Plenty of vacation time as long as you take it according to the student breaks (winter, spring, summer break).
cons:
Any and all students are accepted. No standards for entry are present. Online students are the worst, some can barely read or write. They are simply not ready / prepared to make a serious attempt at higher education.
Students feel entitled to a good / passing grade because they paid a high price for the class...
The classes are only 4 weeks which does not allow for the subject material to be fully explored and practiced.
Upper management only cares about bottom line dollar amounts.
Upper management reduces the quality / challenge of courses so more students can pass.
This is first and foremost a business and not a school.

job_title: Operations/Security in Winter Park, FL
pros: Treated well.. After six months you get one week vacation and 4 gift days.. Three sick days first six monthsthe. then at the year markyou receive 5 more sick days and two weeks of vacation.. Very generous with sick and vacation..
cons: Very low pay. And in my department you don't get a raise based on Merritt.. So if you go above and beyond.. Never miss work.. Cover as shifts when others call out..  Work over time when asked. Never have any corrective counseling or write ups you still get a 2% raise. like the guy that aways calls in sick. Never works overtime. sits on there butts and don't diligently conduct there duty.. That is a little dishearting.

review_title: For the most part, a really groovy place to work, but it is very much dependent upon your position and department.
job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: In my current position, I enjoy the flexibility. Although I would prefer to earn a higher salary, the flexibility allows me to pursue part-time opportunities on a second job to increase my income. In addition, as a creative type, in a nation where jobs for creative types are smaller than the amount of the population who is creative, Full Sail University has a strong footprint in offering creative type opportunities and alternatives.
cons: The salary could be higher, but is competitive for the area. Depending on the position or department, some employees have too much work on their plate.

review_title: Faculty Want More Work From Home
job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Garry Jones, Talented Faculty, Innovative Programs/Educational Model
cons: Health insurance (specifically for families), Office hours on campus (which seems needless)

review_title: A good place to work, but with a need for improvement.
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: It's constant dependable work, with little chance of your career being pulled out from under you.  There is also ample opportunity to network with others.  I also have lots of vacation time with a very good benefits.  I have full medical and dental coverage, which helps with starting a family.
cons: There is too much red tape.  It takes literally YEARS to get anything new accomplished.  In some cases four or five years.  There is not a lot of interaction between senior management and the "lower" help.  I don't even know what half of the people in upper management look like, and I've worked there for over five years.

review_title: Pretty great environment to work in, not much opportunity in career advancement as a lab specialist
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros:
+ Affords plenty of time to work on side projects.
+ Great opportunity to brush up on personal skills by interacting with students.
+ Holiday parties are pretty fun.
cons:
- Advancement is difficult, but not impossible, if you continue to accrue 4+ years of industry experience on the side.
- Can sometimes feel like you're a "cog in the machine"
- There's a mixture of people who still do things "the old way" and those who do things "the new way", which could lead to some problems and confusion. Some Course Directors delegate entirely too much of their responsibilities to Lab Specialists, and it's unclear whether or not that's allowed.

review_title: Great work culture but it's all about POLITICS
job_title: Designated School Official in Winter Park, FL
pros: One of my favorite things about working here was the "down-to-earth" culture. Most employees were great to work with and the students are very passionate; making it very fulfilling to help them achiever their educational goals.
cons: Management is terrible. Very corporate-like environment where it's all about numbers. Management is very "clique-ish" which I feel is incredibly inappropriate for a place of business. The workplace shouldn't be a hangout spot. If you aren't part of the clique or can't find a way "in", good luck moving up. Also, pay is embarassing. This school makes A TON OF MONEY. Why aren't employees compensated properly? It's actually quite despicable. Lots of sleeping around with managers/employees, employees/employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Helping students succeed
Flexible schedule 
Great coworkers 
Casual atmosphere 

If you aren't concerned with the occasional overnight shift and are looking for consistent pay with benefits, this might be a good option for you.
cons:
Erratic schedule 
Poor downward communication from upper management 
For profit education in general has issues 
Pay isn't competitive 

The schedule is flexible both ways. You need to be available for various shifts which include the occasional overnight shift and working weekends. This will change monthly. 

Aside from that, the biggest concern is the communication channel and styles from upper management. They tend to be one way directives and often without weight given to suggestions and concerns from the people actually doing the job. Unfortunately, this has been getting worse instead of better.

review_title: Full Sail University.....A Job not a career
job_title: Marketing Department in Orlando, FL
pros: This is a place where you come in and put your 40 hours and that it I am not required to do work outside of the office. The office work is very easy and is not high pressure, very casual work environment.
cons: Very hard understanding what is expected of you from immediate managers. Projects not explained fully constantly repeating projects over and over because full details are never given for end results. Health benefits are very weak compared to other universities in the area. Current Managers are managers because of  “Time” not because they are qualified. Salary offered is below average for similar work at other Universities

review_title: Lab instructor responsible for four lectures per month and teaching in a lab environment as well.
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: The people are great as well as the students.  The atmosphere is very laid back and it's easy to make friends and work on your own projects.
cons: The hours are terrible.  I had to work times that ranged from 5 am to 1 am and my schedule was never consistent.  Switching from a 5 am shift to a 5 pm shift in less than 24 hours is not easy and the hours do not really allow employees to have much of a life outside working there, unless you can find other people who stay up all night and go to sleep when the sun rises.  I felt I deserved to be payed more as well.  I was paid just barely enough to survive and that was it.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Managers are very relaxed, and the overall culture is good. There is a great deal of flexibility for Instructors who are allowed work from home a few days a week, otherwise I believe they would have a mass exodus.
cons: Most of the upper management team have recently earned online terminal degrees, unfortunately those degrees are from those less than desirable PhD and EdD factories, suspect to say the least.  Recently it was suggested (by upper management) that the Graduate programs change the grading criteria to pass/fail for all courses, what a joke, but quality of education is really not in their wheelhouse! Last but not least, those of color should apply elsewhere.

job_title: Compliance Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: Not many companies give as much time off as this company did.  If you had over 5 years with them you had 3 weeks vacation and they also gave you an additional week off for Christmas. I will miss that.
cons: This is a university that thrives on creativity.  Sometimes the creativeness gets in the way of follow through. They changed things so quickly it was sometimes hard to adjust with so many changes. They need train young reps on how to slow down and speak more clearly.

job_title: Lab Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros:
Relaxed for the most part
Flexible hours
Benefits (Although family cost is high)
Good people
Overtime
Networking
cons:
Pay is low
Too many shoots to be on which consumes your life
Management is content with letting with school sink as long as they're getting their pay check
Upper management cancels meetings to go over things to improve in a course and never reschedules
Unfair pay gaps
Lab specialist work 4 times harder than the Course Directors and make 20k less
CD's work 2 lectures a month and make 50k+ while Lab specialists work 2 60+ hour weeks every month and get ridiculous salaries.

review_title: Not traditional education! No where near it....and that's not good
job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Pay is surprisingly good.
I have a lot of autonomy in developing the course I teach. 
You get a new MacBook Pro.
cons: Corporation first, school second. It's so corporate it takes months for promotions to kick in pay-wise. Any experienced educator will see right through Full Sail's erroneous view of excellent education. The school is built on vocational education, not academic education. Actually, they denounce academic education in a cult-like manner, which makes it difficult to find qualified educators. They are more interested in faculty with only professional experience. This probably works in some areas.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Park, FL
pros: The work and people are great. There are a lot of bonuses to working at such a creative place and the variety of work is one of them. The peers are amazing and unique. The vacation time is pretty good after you’ve been there 5 years. The equipment, software, and gear provided is perfect for getting the job done.
cons: The management in certain departments are inexperienced and reviews are consistently severely late. Vacation time does increase from 5 years to the 20 year mark. There aren’t really defined career paths for growth.

review_title: Cool school but Heavily micro-managed call center environment
job_title: Online Admissions Guide in Winter Park, FL
pros:
You'll meet some great colleagues and talk to some pretty cool students
Events on campus are pretty cool to attend but are few and far between
A great in-between job
cons:
Salary is really really low. I have friends in retail jobs at the mall making more money.
Heavy micro-managed environment 
Stuck on a dialer most of the day saying the same message over-and-over again
Heavy stats driven department which is driven more by the fear of not getting a write-up
Little to no paid benefits
Communication and processes were really bad

review_title: Best people and best place to work
job_title: Editor/Writer in Winter Park, FL
pros: Everyone in my department was professional and nice. I had plenty of training and a great boss. Many people stay at FS for years and years. Garry hugs everyone and calls you "buddy" and it is genuine. We always got a gift vacation week during the week of Christmas or New Year's that didn't count toward your vacation hours. And we got to go home early many times. Sad that I had to move and leave this job.
cons: Hm... Once they laid off a bunch of people for the first time ever. It was scary... But all the higher ups were truly upset about it. That was the only time it happened. Can't think of much else. I guess it depends on your dept. though.

review_title: Not as good as it seems
job_title: Admissions in Winter Park, FL
pros: Good benefits and overall they try to instill a positive culture among students and staff.
cons: No growth opportunities. The job and the environment is nothing like it seems as a result employees are extremely unhappy. The university is at a transition stage, lot of change going on and the well being of employees is not at all being considered. Everyday the amount of work and the expectations increase but there is no true recognition or proper communication. Management has favorites and that causes a very negative work place. The Admissions environment is all about numbers and sales so it makes the every day very stressful.

review_title: Flexible with hours, but lots of micromanagement.
job_title: Default Prevention Officer in Orlando, FL
pros: Flexible scheduling. Fairly casual dress. Easy work load. Fun events fairly often. Many younger people on staff. Garry Jones (CEO) is seriously the nicest guy ever. Newish offices/equipment. Improvements to processes can take a long time to show up, but are incredibly useful when implemented.
cons: Tedious, repetitive job. Almost zero autonomy. Management does not care for suggestions. Lots of micromanagement. Critique meetings for miniscule problems (typing an extra space between words in contact notes, nail biting). It is suggested at the start that lateral/upward movement is easy and happens often, but in practice this doesn't seem to be the case. Difficult to acquire new equipment if it's needed, like headsets, ergonomically friendly chairs (possibly just the case in my department, as others I know do not have this issue).

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Excellent visual environment and it's exciting!  Gary Jones is one of the most decent, talented and effective leaders in the industry.  He has my utmost respect and admiration.  This is a person that means what he says!
cons: Full Sail has the same constraints as every other University so your work (in some cases) is dictated by accreditation rules which can be frustrating

job_title: Manager in Winter Park, FL
pros: The school has a vibrant culture and leadership is always looking for ways to be innovative.  There is a family atmosphere among the workgroups, and management tends to be flexible with scheduling and understanding work/life balance.
cons: Compensation is not competitive and recently there have been freezes on hiring, so we are unable to replace separated employees.  Oftentimes, leadership launches new initiatives without fully considering the effects on each department and the student experience.  There seems to be a disconnect between upper leadership and front-line employees who interact directly with students.

review_title: Great Place With Some Flaws, Sure, But What Place Doesn't?
job_title: Associate Course Director in Orlando, FL
pros: I came to Full Sail with a bit of distrust.  I needed a full-time teaching job, so accepting a position at a for-profit school felt like a Faustian bargain.  I am happy to report that Full Sail is a pretty terrific place, and the department I teach in is serious, rigorous, and committed to faculty development (both personal and professional).  Yes, there are small issues.  Because Full Sail is open enrollment, as an instructor you sometimes wish you could tell a student who clearly cannot handle the work to run for the hills and save 60 grand.  To be fair, Full Sail is not a diploma mill.  Other for-profits give for-profits like Full Sail a bad name by association.  Our department fails students regularly; it has integrity.  FS has made some recent improvements, such as booting out students who do not make it through their very first course.  It's not perfect, and, yes, it's sad to see so many "lost" students getting into debt for a degree that has value but only limited value (if you decide that you do not want to work in the entertainment industry, your FS education is largely worthless), but we have lots of talented students, too, who, when they do the work and thrive definitely find an entry-level opening into their career fields.  Compensation is decent considering that Orlando has fairly low cost of living.
cons: The president is genuine and friendly, but there are a lot of corporate types here.  Orientation was very much like a corporate function: lots of rah-rah about the school, lots of motivational speeches, lots of emphasis on "synergy" and other BS terms from the corporate world.  Really, I thought that I had made the biggest mistake of my life.  Then I went to work for my department and found that it was much more serious and even academic, much like any department at the college level.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Winter Park, FL
pros: Paid time off, Managers don't understand whats going on so its easy to slack off.
cons: Where do i begin.  OAG 1 and OAG 2 do the exact same thing but they have the two sides in constant competition because one side is super strict(oag1) and the other one is not (oag2). Your job is to take inbound calls and try and get the students to start classes in one of the start dates.  Managers are super week and only 1 (damien) is coherent in sales.  The others are out of date with what it takes to be successful.  They have no organization as far as what reps should strive for and they change whats important every other month.  They make up this story that they care about the student when they enroll anyone and watch incompetent people fail.

job_title: Open Lab Monitor in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Being an Open lab monitor is:
- A great way to meet and get to know anyone that comes into your lab. 
- If you have homework from classes that you need to get done, you can work on your it in your lab. Or you can use the lab machines for personal projects.
cons:
- Due to classes going on during the day, the times available to sign up for open labs are usually 7pm- 7am, and it is sometimes a rush to get the afternoon hours first. 
- The labs are sometimes really cold. 
- If you get sign up for labs in the morning it can sometimes mess with your sleep schedule.

job_title: Financial Aid Student Advisor in Winter Park, FL
pros: The president would occasionally spring for happy hours.
cons: None of the people in management positions are qualified to hold their titles. They would rather lay off a single mother with 10+ years of experience to promote an idiot who graduated with one of their own worthless degrees. They once let a homeless person drive across country only to show up so that a lower-level employee could tell them they couldn't afford to go to school there. They are the reason why the Gainful Employment Act (as bad as it is) exits. This school but thousands of students in $40K-worth of debt at interest rates exceeding 20% so the owner could buy some more classic cars and purchase more land in Winter Park.

review_title: Full Sail University is the best place I have ever worked.
job_title: Program Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Full Sail University is a magical place that fosters community and growth for students and employees.  There are continuing education and specialized leadership training opportunities.  Working with students is fulfilling and inspirational.  While the company is large, employees feel supported and there is a family-like atmosphere.  Furthermore, there is never a dull moment.  Well-known entertainment industry guests frequently visit the school to talk to students and faculty, Full Sail has countless community partnerships that allow students to gain real-world experience, and there is constant innovation.
cons: Innovation leads to constant change so team members must be agile.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Amazing schedule (3 days on campus, 2 at home or on the road, per week), fantastic benefits (great healthcare, matching 401k, discounts, other perks...), access to facilities and equipment
cons: Because this is primarily a tech school, a lot of the managers aren't actually professional managers. They are industry professionals who decided to teach for one reason or another. For that reason, they are often not very good at managing people and projects. Though this technically is a corporate environment, it very much does not feel like one (though that might not be a con for a lot of people).

review_title: Great place, but really low pay.
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: You get to work on the best equipment, and the people you work with are cool.
cons: There's nowhere to go.  If I don't get my Masters degree, then I can't move up, but nobody gets a Masters degree in my field.  The pay is super low, so you should just take the job to get the experience, but you won't be able to pay your bills.  Management never tells us anything.  Things just happen with no explanation.

review_title: The people at Full Sail University are passionate and believe if the founder's mission: giver every student a chance.
job_title: Administration in Winter Park, FL

job_title: Senior Enhancement Specialist in Winter Park, FL

Management wouldn't display performance metrics as they didn't want to embarrass anyone.  Your lazy coworkers will ride your coat tails as to give you more responsibility. review_title: Amazing leadership, loving culture, inspiring work

Paid Holidays
Employee Christmas Party
Paid Tuition

job_title: in Winter Park, FL

review_title: They don’t take your dreams seriously
job_title: Campus Admissions in Winter Park, FL
pros: Coworkers- the only saving grace here
cons:
Crappy schedule 
Horrible upper management 
Very focused on stats
Horrific Work environment 
Bad culture

job_title: Director, Staff & Cultural Development in Orlando, FL
pros:
I've invested 23 years of my professional career with Full Sail University. This is not a decision someone makes lightly. The primary reasons include, but aren't limited to: 

Our enduring endeavor to take dreams seriously 

The passion of our students who will do what it takes to fan the spark of their professional desires into the radiant flames of realized career dreams 

Our extraordinary staff, faculty, and leadership who understand their responsibility of taking dreams seriously - knowing that realized dreams are the greatest gifts our students can give to the world 

Our culture that's  rooted deeply in our DNA, governed by our guiding principles, infused with the creativity of our passionate students, and generated by our deeply caring faculty and staff.
cons: Our mission and educational model is unique and demanding. It's with good reason - to prepare our students for fiercely competitive industries. We would be doing our students a great disservice if we only educated and trained them: we also must condition them for the rigors of careers not suited for the "faint of heart." To service our educational mission and model and deliver it will integrity - we need professionals who are at excellent at their craft and who resonate with the fast-paced rhythm of our degree programs - and all that goes into supporting the model. This is more of a "heads-up" (vs. a con) to those seriously considering a Full Sail career. Our careers are very rewarding, but very demanding. Of course, successful professionals know the two go hand-in-hand - regardless of context.

job_title: Student Liaison in Orlando, FL
pros: Great company to work for.  People actually smile with you as you walk around the campus and you can feel the "family hug" environment.  Direct management in my department is extremely understanding and works with you throughout life events/other factors that may come up.  Full Sail is the only organization that I have worked for that gives specific holiday perks such as time off and dedicated "employee celebrations".
cons: Advancement can be temperamental and the compensation off-sided depending on the department.

job_title: Management in Winter Park, FL
pros: There are some great people working there.  The work environment is modern and inspiring.  It’s almost impossible to get fired.
cons: The pay varies too much from person to person.  There are senior members of leadership who are more interested in the paycheck rather than the company.  Most are not qualified for their roles either.   These leaders are what keep the place from growing and seeing its potential.  It’s a shame.

review_title: Both the best and worst job I've ever had, so if you're serious about education, you will be frustrated.
job_title: Associate Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: It tends to be an environment where creativity and professional growth are encouraged, including personal projects fulfilled with company resources.  Good one-on-one time with students.  A lax dress code, somewhat accommodating schedule, and very seldom do you have someone looking over your shoulder.
cons: There is no opportunity for advancement, even with higher degrees and experience levels.  Promotions tend to be based on social interaction, not performance.  There are no meritorious raises, only across-the-board cost-of-living increases that reward everyone equally regardless of performance.  They are unsure of their identity as either a school or a business, and this causes several problems, including enrolling every student, regardless of ability, to swell their income.  There is no cap on student enrollment so class sizes balloon frequently and are constantly on the rise, robbing individual students of equal education opportunities, and additional equipment and personnel do not increase to match.  On paper they encourage their teachers to remain working professionals, but seldom is time allowed for this.  The monthly scheduling allows little time for personal investment in a student's professional/personal growth.  As a 24-hour, 7-days-a-week facility, one's personal schedule tends to be all over the place, allowing little in the way of organizing your personal/family time, planning meals/diet, and getting quality sleep/exercise.   The lax environment many times encourages laziness in some employees, which burdens the dedicated ones, robs students of quality educations, and still gets rewarded (or overlooked) by management.  The frustrations felt by students concerning managerial and administrative decisions always get vented to teachers, who are given non-effective propaganda to handle it.

review_title: Is it a School or a Business? The Paradox of Full Sail "University"
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: Full Sail offers a very casual atmosphere in terms of dress code, adherence to a timeclock, and monitoring the execution of one's tasks.  The job maintains a certain level of freshness and satisfaction due to an ever-changing student body eager to learn from your experience.  They offer certain departments the opportunity to use company equipment to further your own personal projects and professional growth.  Some departments also turn a blind eye to docking you for personal and vacation days used.
cons: There is little to no opportunity for advancement.  The work becomes extremely monotanous very quickly due to a repetition of duties each month, and it consistently increases in magnitude because there is no cap on the number of students the school enrolls.  There is a conflict of interest between business and education since the school is "for profit".  So grades are not binding, actual instruction is downplayed in favor of larger, sucessful graduating classes, and marketing trumps all else, focusing more on prospective students than on the needs of current ones.  Management is inconsistent and somewhat hypocritical with their communication, making last-minute demands on staff while taking too long to respond to necessary staff inquiries.  And since they favor email, there is a tendancy to read emotion into typed words that does not exist, then unjustly act upon that implication without confirmation.  Lastly, a large portion of their staff pool are recent graduates of the school who usually do not have the real world experience to adequately teach the necessary information, yet they receive the same amount of pay as seasoned veterans.  And that pay is below local standards.

review_title: My experience at Full Sail University has been active and engaging, as well as rewarding.
job_title: Lab Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: Personally, one of my favorite things is that Full Sail likes to treat their employees pretty well. Parties happen a couple of times a year to celebrate faculty and staff. Not to mention the work environment is very stress-free.
cons: Students can have a really wonderful effect on how good or bad your day goes. I say this as a 'con' because sometimes you get a couple of months in a row with a rough group of students.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orlando, FL
pros: Fun events, holiday perks and time off, good benefits
cons: Messy and confusing management from the top all the way down. All decisions are made based on money, getting students in the door, and making the school look good. Stressful and not worth it considering salaries are extremely low.

review_title: Amazing journey of great experiences and awesome people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Park, FL
pros: Able to work with a good schedule with flexibility for appointment and other commitments. Always an environment to learn and grow as a professional and a person. Enjoy all of the extra activities and benefits the campus and department offer on an annual basis.
cons: Opportunity for higher compensation based on experience and qualification.

job_title: Admissions Connection Specialist in Winter Park, FL
pros: Coworkers and managers are top notch. No drama, lots of fun, always understanding and leanient. Most people in my division were promoted within 1 yr. and overtime- I'm eligible for up to 30 hours a week.
cons: It's incredible how well everyone gets along. My department works in close teams, so if you only want to focus on your work and never relax, you might hate it. Disrespectful people simply are not hired. Only downfall is there are very few part time positions available.

job_title: Course Director in Orlando, FL
pros: I can't say enough about working at Full Sail, I hate to call it a company because it's really like a community made up of different families (degree programs and support services). They value your experience and expertise and everyone from the President to the support staff are here to support the instructors and students. Truly a wonderful place to work.
cons: Balance workload and outside life - we are growing so fast that my class size has reached 100 students most months. Which really should dictate two courses directors not one.

review_title: Good for just out of school work but not long hall.
job_title: Financial Aid Administrator in Winter Park, FL
pros: The people I worked with were awesome.  We were all about the same age (mid to late 20's) so it was easy for us to get along.  After many meetings morale would drop but within an hour or so of speaking to everyone we'd ease back into working together.  They trained us as new hires (actually trained us, not just a video), which is so far the best introduction to a position I've had.  I'd say about half of the manager's there are there for the employees.  Unfortunately this means they wast e a lot of time arguing with the other half about what's more important, people/students or money.  Also, Garry is a genuinely good guy.
cons: There's no real structure, after you are put live you're pretty much left with an outdated system.  Trying to change something basically means talking to 6 manager's for months and getting a "we'll work on it", with not much action.  There is a lot of talk about working in a team but when you speak out to other departments about improvement some manager's feel like you've gone around them and take issue with it.  Lastly, and I've touched on this already, many of the upper management seems disconnected from what actually is involved in their employees positions.  Many times we'd have meetings where a manager would tell us how our job was performed only to have an outburst from many employees who couldn't believe how far off the manager actually was.  This led to low morale many times (at least once a month to be more precise, usually the week before a start).  Fortunately, the people actually doing the job with you are good people and are able to lean on each other in these times to get the job done.  (Good for employee to employee connections, bad for employee to management).

review_title: Fun work environment, but very numbers-driven, with poor management.
job_title: Online Enrollment Guide in Winter Park, FL
pros: Great coworkers, lots of food, awesome Christmas events for staff and their families. The job was fairly easy, and there was a great level of autonomy if you did job.
cons: Terrible management, call center environment, no work/life balance. We worked 6 days a week for months straight , and were constantly pushed to start more students. Favoritism exists, so qualifications don't really matter if you get in good with management.

review_title: Not the best place to work, not the worst.
job_title: in Orlando, FL

cons: The pay is low and the cubicles are small. If you do receive a promotion, the raise will be small.

job_title: Intern in Winter Park, FL
pros: While I was there all the instructors were very helpful with any questions or critiques. They were a critical asset to completing work, and sometimes troubleshooting issues.

job_title: Tier II Inbound Support Specialist in Orlando, FL

cons: If you love what you do and you love the department you're in, it can be easy to become complacent.

review_title: Textbook Example of a Toxic Workplace
job_title: Teacher in Winter Park, FL
pros: The only positive experience with this company was working with students on a daily basis and seeing them actually learning something.
cons: This company is a textbook example of a "toxic workplace".  Narcissism, nepotism, shady business practices, questionable education techniques, low morale and a creepy, cult-like devotion to senior managers define the corporate culture here.  If you come here thinking you are actually going to be a teacher you will soon find yourself frustrated.  The fact that admissions counselors make 3 times as much money as instructors should be an immediate red flag.  Many instructors don't make it past the first few months.  Most of the people at the top of this company graduated from the school and immediately went to work there without any real experience in the real world.  Almost all of the staff are under-qualified and it shows in the quality of their classes.  The company literature touts the staff as "industry professionals" but most have little practical experience in their industry.  12 hour days and overnight shifts are common.  The hours leave little time for any outside social activities and internal social activities are required with attendance being taken.  Seriously, what kind of company actually does that?  The senior management only speaks to underlings condescendingly if at all.  Communication is one way.  Management does not respond to e-mails or phone calls but if you don't respond to their requests immediately....even if you are in the middle of a class...you will be in big trouble.  The senor management doesn't seem to socialize with anyone outside the company and a large number of them are married to other senior managers which makes the atmosphere very strange.  Morale is low and you always feel like someone is watching you ready to pounce at the first mistake.  Student numbers are down and management's solution was to freeze pay raises, cut off bonuses and reduce hours.  They will still spend millions of dollars on parties and celebrations...events that requires staff to do all of the manual labor but they claim they are unable to pay a living wage.  Lower level management is abusive and petty and the entire atmosphere seems like an out-of-control grade school playground with the bullies at the top of the food chain.  Much of the instruction that students pay in excess of $80,000 consists of being being told to watch YouTube and Lynda videos.  For the last four years several of my classes were taught using broken and out-of-date gear.  If you are an educator or an industry professional older than 25 years old you will not last here.  If you see your job as running faceless dollar signs through the program to make room for more faceless dollar signs you might actually survive.  Never forget that this is a business first and a school last.  You are there to serve the owners and not the students. If you really care about education do yourself a favor run away from this place.  Your mental and physical health will suffer and when you burn out you will be swept out the door like so much garbage.

job_title: in Tampa, FL
pros: As a student of the school, they were very accommodating with scheduling and never treated part-time student employees as less a part of the team than full-time employees.
cons: Many rumors of scams and dissatisfaction surround the school because of its unique nature; therefore you may deal with a variety of naysayers depending on the position.

review_title: Wonderful, creative people work here. Several people in top management don't listen and micromanage.

review_title: Working at Full Sail allowed me access to some of the Entertainment Industries best professionals.

job_title: Associate Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: THe students a very dedicated and the curriculum really set them up for success. THe class sizes are great there are 3 instructors or assistants present at a 12/1 ratio.
cons: 24 hour class schedule. THere is no real focus on scheduling. Therefore, the over night instructors are not supported, due to the fact the directors are there from 9am -5pm. This is the most challenging aspect when teaching at Full Sail.

job_title: Associate Course Director in Casselberry, FL
pros:
Company Benefits
Other instructors 
Occasional flex days

Not much else to say here as the great things about Full Sail are now long gone.
cons:
Started out great, but recent changes made a lot of people leave. They won’t rehire and as an employee, or “Full Sail Family Member” you’re expected to pick up extra classes and multiple students with little to no overtime or adjunct pay. 

A lot of instructors are taking on more classes that they can handle, yet they are all still expected to find the free time to work on their own art. They want good, fast, and cheap all the time and no less. There’s no down time to fix or review your own curriculum when you’re pulling in a new class every month. 

You’ll quickly find that trying to get quality work out of these students isn’t what they want. They want them pushed through the degree mill and you’re a well oiled cog in that machine. They allow students who are repeating to submit their work that they’ve already had graded multiple times. This allows for a lot of grey areas for the student to constantly fight their grades. 

Get used to the idea that students have more power than instructors. Students are allowed to file formal complaints on a whim, so if a student decides they don’t like you for some trivial reason, like they got mad that you caught them plagiarizing work from the internet, they can file a formal complaint. This then triggers a massive investigation of all of your e-mail correspondence between students, recorded phone calls, and chat logs. If your superiors decide you were in the wrong for any reason what so ever, you have to retake continuing education classes on communication and are written up.

They promise promotions year after year and then give the promotions to people who are less qualified with less work experience, but are easy for upper management to manipulate. They will give you the work of the same promotion because the person they promoted isn’t qualified to do the work, yet not pay you to pick up the slack.

Stay away. They do not care for their staff like they used to and it’s a mess. Speaking up only puts a target on your back and you’ll be quickly managed out of your position. HR States they know of the issues but there isn’t anything they can do about it.

Upper management 
Raise cuts
Work to life ratio
No respect for instructors anymore

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: Colleagues are very resourceful. Benefits are decent. But it is not the place to build a career unless one cannot find something better. It is truly a dead end job and unless one is friends with department heads, you are not moving up.

Frustrating for students since they'll be the ones to flip a major bill after graduating. If the school advertises that students are taught by industry professionals, then give them industry pros in the classroom. The 'trainings' for educators (called CEs for short) are ridiculous and a waste of time. Very little valuable information is dispensed. Also, there are a lot of 'educators' that do not have the proper academic credentials; they would not be able to hold jobs in traditional education (for example: people with Bachelors, people with high school degrees, people with no degrees). Makes you wonder how they managed to qualify for national accreditation; FS would never qualify for regional because they are too loose in their standards. On a final note, other educators are being hired straight out of school - not exactly what FS would let their prospective students to believe about instructors having industry experience.

job_title: Course Director in Winter Park, FL
pros: You will learn a lot working there, like how to present well to a group, dealing with people (students and staff), etc. Good skills to pick up for working elsewhere in the "real world". The "good" students were wonderful and fun to teach. Most teachers work hard to do the best for the students, as do middle managers. The organization throws big, fancy parties with free food and drinks. Employees get some "free" vacation days as a gift around the holidays, of course in lieu of a financial bonus. Benefits are okay.  Might be low-stress if you get the right boss/department.
cons:
Minor: No faculty parking. Vacation allotment is typical of businesses (this is a business, not a school - don't kid yourself. You get two weeks when you start.)
Major: Upper management doesn't listen to or value their people. They have a very top-down management style. Your concerns are not a priority unless it is something that exposes them to legal liability, then they'll move quick. For a long time, to move up in this organization you needed to hang out and drink with some of the managers. If it's still that way, your competence has nothing to do with your value to this organization, but if you kiss enough butt, certainly you'll move up at some point if they like you as a drinking buddy. Some management is passive-aggressive, and sometimes they blanket rules on everyone rather than address a couple of individuals they have the problem with. 

Another poster mentioned the "if they don't like it, they can quit" attitude. I can attest that attitude was witnessed by me several times from different managers. It's demotivating to hear managers say that about their workers, and I can only assume that is the attitude up the ladder. 

They receive tax money in the form of student loans that were meant for educational services for serious students, yet there's no aptitude testing or real assessment of any kind for enrollment. It really is about maximizing money. If you can stomach being a cog in a "school" like this, go for it. And they seem to like to spend money on their Behind the Scenes open houses and on the Admissions department, and less on education (pay was low, especially a few years ago).
